title: Fire & Blood
subtitle: A Targaryen History #1
author: George R. R. Martin
description: The first of two volumes (I'll believe it when I see it, George), Fire and Blood tells the story of the Targaryens from Aegon the Conqueror's landing in Westeros through the Dance of the Dragons until Aegon III comes of age. Fire and Blood feels encyclopedic. The writing is terse and matter of fact, though Martin's clever prose sneak through. Really, though, this book is just for fans in love with the world of Fire and Ice who just crave more epic worldbuilding.

title: All Systems Red
author: Martha Wells
description: A fast-paced novella about a Deadpool-esque sentient security robot who, against its best wishes, cares for its human companions as they try to survive on a remote planet where everything is not as it seems.

title: Berlin
subtitle: City of Stones
author: Jason Lutes
description: A beautiful black and white graphic novel set in 1928 Berlin that follows a wide range of characters, particularly journalist Kurt Severing and artist Marthe Muller, as tempers flare and the world darkens around them. While gorgeous and captivating at times, this felt like a slog in sections: and accomplishment for a 200-page graphic novel.

title: Bossypants
author: Tina Fey
description: An uproariously funny memoir of Tina Fey's childhood, early improve comedy career, and success with SNL and 30 Rock. Organized as a guide to being a successful leader of creative-types, Fey's writing bounces between insightful, reflective, and laugh-out-loud hilarous from one sentence to the next.

title: Stories of Your Life and Others
author: Ted Chiang
description: While less focused than his second book, Exhalation, Chiang's first short story collection is mesmerizing. The first tale, Tower of Babylon was his first published story and still managed to win a Hugo. Stories of Your Life became the hit-movie Arrival. Other stories explore alternate histories in which scientific discoveries evolved differently. Despite the high-concepts, his stories always feel grounded in human characters allowing readers to explore strange worlds that still somehow feel like the one we inhabit.

title: Talking to Strangers
subtitle: What We Should Know about the People We Don't Know
author: Malcom Gladwell
description: You know Gladwell's shtick. Take one part social psychology study, another part of a current event reinterpreted, finally add a heaping spoonful of rhetorical questions and you've got a Gladwell book. Yet, I can't help but find myself curiosity piqued by the stories and research he juxtaposes. Am I always convince by his conclusions? No. But, this book is by far his most thought provoking for how it frames infamous public figures -- Amanda Knox, Brock Turner, Jerry Sandusky. For me, this stands with The Tipping Point as his best works.

title: In the Garden of Beasts
subtitle: Love, Terror, and an American Family in Hitler's Berlin
author: Erik Larson
description: A meticulously researched portrait of a country descending into Nazisms through the eyes of the American ambassador and his family. While some parts were fascinating, all but the most curious World War II buffs will find this one a bit slow.

title: Home After Dark
subtitle: A Novel
author: David Small
description: Small's works are always beautiful and this novel tells the story of Russel Pruitt. After his mother's abandonment, Russell and his father pack the car and make for California, eventually settling in remote Marshfield. Once there Russel is left to fend for himself as he discovers what it means to grow into a young man. This book might appeal to graphic novel skeptics looking for more literature and less comic book.

title: Exhalation
subtitle: Stories
author: Ted Chiang
description: From the author of the short story that became the hit movie Arrival, a beautiful, philosophical collection of nine stories exploring time travel, free will, and artificial intelligence.

title: Blood, Sweat, and Pixels
subtitle: The Triumphant, Turbulent Stories Behind How Video Games Are Made
author: Jason Schreier
description: Blood, Sweat, and Pixels is a compelling read for fans of video games. Schreier tells the story of how 10 games -- from triple-A, big budget games like Diablo III to one-person projects like Stardew Valley -- get made (or not) and all of the corporate politics and challenges that get in the way. If you’ve ever wondered how a development team can spend years and millions on a game that is obviously terrible, this book will help you understand.

title: Un-Trumping America
subtitle: A Plan to Make America a Democracy Again
author: Dan Pfeiffer
description: A much stronger work than his first book, Yes We (Still) Can, host of the popular lefty podcast, Pod Save America, outlines a vision for how Democrats can regain power in American politics. Mixing media strategy expertise, White House experience, and hard-hitting humor, Pfeiffer makes a compelling case for more aggressive tactics by Democrats.

title: Caffeine
subtitle: How Caffeine Created the Modern World
author: Michael Pollan
description: The famous food and drug writer tackles caffeine in this just-for-audible audiobook. With his usual mix of curiosity, clever writing, and self-experimentation, Pollan shares how coffee (really its psychoactive compounds) spread across the world from the Middle East and revolutionized society all the while sharing his personal experience of giving up his daily dose (or doses) of the drug.

title: The Last Wish
subtitle: Introducing the Witcher
author: Andrzej Sapkowski
description: Meet Geralt of a Rivia, a genetically modifed monster hunter with a rye wit and reluctant commitment to doing good. This collection of short stories is a great introduction to the the world of The Witcher that became a Netflix series and smash-hit videogame.

title: Why We're Polarized
author: Ezra Klein
description: I’ve learned more from Ezra Klein and his podcast than perhaps any other person. So it is no surprise that Klein has crafted an insightful and original analysis of our current politics. Klein clearly articulates how our identities, once broken into many unrelated parts, have now aligned dramatically at two poles. Weaving in historical research, social psychology, and modern politics, Klein’s new book manages to live up to the promise of its title without retreading the same gut-feeling explanations seen elsewhere.

title: The Night Circus
author: Erin Morgenstern
description: A whimsical tale full of magic, mystery, and romance, The Night Circus is unlike any other fantasy novel you’ve read. It tells the story of two magicians playing a game they don’t really understand. This novel is packed with curious characters who hold their secrets close until the very end.

title: Daytripper
author: Gabriel Ba and Fabio Moon
description: Daytripper visits alternate realities of Bras de Olivias Dominguez’s life. Each chapter is a what-if, exploring the spiraling, haunting repercussions of the choices we all make each day.

title: Light of the Stars
subtitle: Alien Worlds and the Fate of the Earth
author: Adam Frank
description: There are 40 billion habitable planets in the Milky Way, our local galaxy. If only 0.01 percent of those planets have intelligent life, there should be 4 million intelligent civilizations in our galaxy alone. So, where is everybody? This is the Fermi paradox, the crucial idea driving research into extraterrestrial life. Frank’s book serves as a history of the study of aliens, from ancient Greece to modern day. While enjoyable for those already curious about the subject, this is not the most captivating account of the supremely interesting subject.

title: Blindspot
subtitle: Hidden Biases of Good People
author: Mahzarin R. Banaji and Anthony G. Greenwald
description: Your mind does not work the way you think. In fact, most of your brain’s labor is subconscious, hidden and mysterious. We all accept that our brain pumps our blood and blinks our eyes, but we underestimate the power our subconscious has over our opinions and impulses. The magic of this book is the collection of simple experiments you can try that make the power of your subconscious visible. Blind Spot provides indisputable evidence of your implicit biases but is perhaps a bit too much review for those who have taken a collegiate psychology class.
